question: Which of these is NOT an element of culture?
answers: Instincts

question: According to biologist Brian Skerry, what is the difference between behavior and culture?
answers: Behavior is what we do. Culture is how we do it.

question: What is an example of a subculture? (Select all that apply.)
answers: Residents of a city or region within a larger country.
A particular department within an organization.
A group who gathers dressed up in character from a favorite TV show.

question: According to the article in the lecture titled Examples of Cultures, how do we know whales have culture?
answers: Different groups have unique behaviors, languages, and hunting practices, even within the same species.

question: Why does Edgar Schein look at culture like an onion?
answers: Culture has multiple layers that you can only see as you peel them off.

question: In the onion model of culture, what are considered elements you would see in the outer layer?
answers: The clothes people wear or the decorations in their buildings.

question: In the onion model of culture, what are considered elements you would see in the middle layer? (Select all that apply.)
answers: What is written down as values, particularly for an organization.
How we greet each other or the topics we talk about.
The way we do our rituals and traditions - weddings and holidays.

question: Considering the onion concept of culture, what are considered elements you would see in the inner layer? (Select all that apply.)
answers: Things we may be unconscious of, that we assume are how the world works.
Similar elements to everyone else's inner layers.

question: Why is it important not to make assumptions based on an organization's surface culture?
answers: Surface culture is only a small portion of an overall culture and does not give the full picture.

question: Considering the iceberg concept of culture, what is considered internal culture in an organization?
answers: Deeply held values, beliefs, and assumptions.

question: Considering the iceberg concept of culture, what is considered surface culture in an organization?
answers: Objective behaviors and practices in interactions that are readily observed and learned.

question: According to the reading in the lecture titled The Iceberg Metaphor, what do organizations with healthy organizational cultures have in common?
answers: They are higher performing, adaptive, and unique.

question: Based on the study on teamwork between chimpanzees in the lecture Defining a Good Team, what do humans and chimpanzees have in common?
answers: Chimpanzees and humans can work together to achieve a common goal.

question: How can team members hold each other accountable?
answers: By engaging in conversation with other members about communicating or delivering on their responsibilities.

question: Based on the Lencioni Model discussion in the lecture Defining a Good Team, how can good teams focus on the collective over the individual? (Select all that apply.)
answers: By building trust among team members.
By engaging in healthy conflict in which differing opinions are discussed.
By gaining commitment from members to act on team decisions.

question: According to the article in the lecture Defining a Good Team, how do we know that chimpanzees can work as a team?
answers: When given tools, chimpanzees were able to understand how to transfer tools to their partner and work together to get the food.

question: What is the difference between healthy and unhealthy team conflict?
answers: Healthy team conflict aims to improve outcomes for the team and is respectful and non-personal. Team conflict is unhealthy when it is personal and destructive.

question: Which of these are psychological needs, according to Maslow in the lecture The Development of Teams? (Select all that apply).
answers: Belonging
Prestige

question: Which of these needs can be applied to team settings? (Select all that apply.)
answers: Security
Belonging
Prestige

question: Which of these will probably be the most difficult stage of group development?
answers: Storming

question: Why do the stages of group development matter?
answers: If you know what the stages include, you can be better prepared for what is coming next and see how to best approach it.

question: Why is diversity on teams important?
answers: Diverse teams bring in different ways of thinking about problems, which allows them to work together more productively.

question: The Big 5 Personality Traits are:
answers: Openness, Conscientiousness, Extraversion, Agreeableness, Neuroticism

question: The Big 5 Personality Traits are universally applicable personality traits. (True or False)
answers: True

question: People who are cooperative and caring of others tend to be high in:
answers: Agreeableness

question: Why does learning about the Big 5 Personality Traits matter for multinational and cross-cultural teams?
answers: It can help us to understand personal differences so that we can appreciate people's unique traits and work together more productively.

question: What does the term "cross" imply in "cross-cultural"?
answers: Both getting to know and integrating with someone else's culture, and them getting to know and integrating with yours.

question: Which of the following do you consider a multinational cross-cultural (MNCC) team? (Select all that apply.)
answers: Team members from multiple cultures, multiple countries in Europe, America, Canada, India, Australia, Far East, and even within different countries, having people of different origins.
A team located in different countries while also having people from different cultural backgrounds in the same room.
People on a team are from different cultures, different countries, and perhaps, speak different languages, like the people working together in the International Space Station.

question: According to the reading in the lecture What is a Multinational Team, why does Phuong Uyen Tran think teamwork "tends to be an alien concept" throughout much of Asia?
answers: Many Asian cultures emphasize not expressing disagreement publicly and showing respect to senior level leaders.

question: According to the article in the lecture What is a Multinational Team, what simple change in behavior can prevent the failure of Western companies trying to import their teamwork-based corporate culture to Asia?
answers: Focus not on teamwork, but the notion of taking responsibility for your individual work and not assigning blame or undue credit to any individual.

question: In the lecture What is a Multinational Team, what structures does Tran recommend leaders put in place to help Asian staff members embrace a teamwork culture?
answers: Reinforce that every time they behave as a collective, what they are actually doing is teamwork.

question: According to the Society for Human Resource Management, what did survey respondents say were the biggest benefits of global teams?
answers: They bring a diversity of thinking, creativity, and talent to their work.

question: In the first reading in the lecture Challenges of a Multinational, Cross-Cultural Team, which of these are listed as a benefit of working in international teams? (Select all that apply.)
answers: Productivity
Creativity
Understand of other cultures
Communication

question: According to the article in the lecture Challenges of a Multinational, Cross-Cultural Team, what happened when an international team of exchange students were given the opportunity to practice addressing real-world problems?
answers: They were able to develop decision-making, problem-solving, and teamwork skills while working across continents.

question: According to the Society for Human Resource Management, what did survey respondents say were the biggest challenges of global teams?
answers: Multiple languages, time zones, and locations creates barriers between teammates, as well as with their customers.

question: Which of these are NOT listed as a core problem for managing international teams in the second reading in Challenges of a Multinational, Cross-Cultural Team lecture?
answers: Work ethics

question: According to the article in Challenges of a Multinational, Cross-Cultural Team, which of these are solutions to apply to language/cultural barriers? (Select all that apply.)
answers: Make objectives and deliverables clear to all team members at each project stage.
Use simpler terms and expressions in English.
Find a happy medium between the more formal and relaxed styles of team members.

question: Why does Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie have a "single story" of what books are?
answers: As a child, she read only British and American children's books.

question: Which of these are NOT "single story" cultural narratives that Adichie has experienced or come across?
answers: African men are educated and middle-class.

question: According to Adichie in the Ted Talk, what is the problem with stereotypes?
answers: It is not that they are untrue, it is that they are incomplete.

question: According to the reading in the lecture Becoming Culturally Aware, what is the "magic of ambiguous images"?
answers: They remind us that perception is subjective.

question: What is the larger takeaway of the reading on ambiguous images?
answers: If two people can look at the same image and see different things, then you should keep that in mind next time you are confronted with an opinion different from your own.

question: Read the following dialogue that Meyer uses in her book to demonstrate communication challenges between high and low context cultures. Mr. Diaz: It looks like some of us are going to have to be here on Sunday to host the client visit. Mr. Chen: I see. Mr. Diaz: Can you join us on Sunday? Mr. Chen: Yes, I think so. Mr. Diaz: That would be a great help. Mr. Chen: Yes, Sunday is an important day. Mr. Diaz: In what way? Mr. Chen: It’s my daughter’s birthday. Mr. Diaz: How nice. I hope you all enjoy it. Mr. Chen: Thank you. I appreciate your understanding. If you were from a low context culture, how would you interpret this dialogue?
answers: Mr. Chen will not join on Sunday for the client visit.

question: Look at this image created by Richard Lewis of Richard Lewis Communications- https://i.insider.com/538605fa6bb3f7172f4e37dd?width=1300&format=jpeg&auto=webp . Which of the following could be true of this image? (Select all that apply.)
answers: A flexible time culture might look at the schedule of the top image, but actually interpret it to mean the bottom image.
The top image is how a linear time culture would fill their daily schedule, and the bottom image is how a flexible time culture would fill their daily schedule.

question: Which of these are true about consensual decision making? (Select all that apply.)
answers: It generally results in something everyone can agree on.
Scandinavian countries tend to utilize consensual decison making practices.
It may take a long time and a lot of meetings.

question: Which of the following were advised by our expert panel as initial ideas on how best to respond to cultural differences on your team? (Select all that apply.)
answers: Read about other cultures and look for commonalities.
Be nice from the beginning to build trust.
Tailor your communication differently to different people.
Be intensely aware of not just what people are saying but their body language.

question: According to the reading in the lecture Skills to Respond to Cultural Differences, which of these factors that need to be taken care of while leading or managing global teams stands out the most?
answers: Cultural differences

question: Which of these is NOT a recommendation from Kulkami on how to understand and handle cultural differences?
answers: Introduce and orient people to the corporate culture.

question: Which of these is NOT a recommendation from Kulkami about ways you can study the cultures from every country where your team members are from?
answers: Travel to all the other countries that your team members are from.

question: Which of these is NOT a recommendation from Kulkami about what you should focus on when you take time to understand every member of your team?
answers: Understand the junior members of a team first.

question: What is "social distance" (think beyond the pandemic related thinking)?
answers: Differences in language, location, culture, and more that can inhibit an emotional connection between people.

question: Which of these is NOT a component of the SPLIT framework for identifying and successfully managing social distance?
answers: Language

question: Which of these are “deliberate moments” that Neeley suggests, in focusing on process, to reduce social distance during meetings? (Select all that apply.)
answers: 5-minute unstructured social time at the top.
Solicit individual input from each team member, starting with those with the least status or experience.

question: Which of these is NOT an example of how to “dial down dominance” to reduce language-based social distance?
answers: Speak up when you don’t understand what someone else is saying.

question: Which of the following are types of non-verbal communication? (Select all that apply.)
answers: Greeting a colleague with a hug or kiss on the cheek
Standing closely to one another

question: While some aspects of non-verbal communication are intentional, many are unintentional and difficult to control. Which of the following are considered difficult to intentionally control? (Select all that apply.)
answers: Physiological cues
Posture
Facial expressions

question: According to Dr. Albert Mahrabian, approximately what percentage of the way we tell if someone likes something comes from their facial expression?
Why is learning to control all aspects of your communication important? (Select all that apply.)
answers: It helps you to become a more efficient communicator.
It increases your chances of successfully communicating with people from many different cultures.

question: When using someone's non-verbal communication to interpret what they are trying to say it is important to: (Select all that apply.)
answers: Remember cultural differences
Consider all the non-verbal communication rather than a single example
Look for inconsistencies

question: Which of the following listening skills are part of the SEER framework created by Daniel Student? (Select all that apply.)
answers: Retention

question: According to the SEER framework, which of the following are true? (Select all that apply.)
answers: Leaning in and nodding often demonstrate empathy
Empathy can be practiced and improved

question: Reflective listening is an important skill that involves two distinct practices. These practices are:
answers: Telling the other person what you think they are saying
Helping the other person better understand their own thoughts

question: As a member of an MNCC team you have a unique role to play when demonstrating how to listen to your colleagues. Improving your listening skills can help other team members grow past the challenges innate in MNCC teams. Those challenges include: (Select all that apply.)
answers: Cultural differences in expressions and communication style
Various accents
Different understandings of the roles of speakers and listeners in ensuring mutual understanding

question: John Wallen proposed a novel approach to improving communication, a process that starts by breaking communication down into various component pieces. Which of the following are not one of those pieces?
answers: The listener's response to the speaker

question: Why might the first step in Wallen's approach to improving communication, paraphrasing, be particularly helpful in an MNCC team? (Select all that apply.)
answers: When working cross culturally, the first challenge is usually one of language; therefore, repeating back in your own words in order to make sure the listener understands what the speaker was actually saying is extremely helpful.

Different cultures have different approaches to making requests or giving directions; paraphrasing what you heard and understood can help ensure both people are on the same page, even with simple matters.

question: Which of the following examples represents someone practicing the third step, description of feelings, in reducing the interpersonal gap well?
answers: "When you raised your voice it made me believe you may feel angry or upset."

question: Imagine that you are looking for a strong project manager. What type of communication style is best for this role?
answers: Any type of communicator might be best, it depends on the other team members and the particular project.

question: While there are many positive ways to interact with a person of every communication style, there are also communication styles you should try to avoid when interacting with them. Which of these should be avoided? (Select all that apply.)
answers: Intuitive - Making Big Promises
Analytical - Emotional Conversation ("I feel...")

question: Based on the Berlitz article, in what business situations are emails most useful?
answers: Emails are useful for communicating information before a phone or in-person meeting, and if there are no sensitive issues involved.

question: How can telephone conferences be organized to improve cross-cultural communication? (Select all that apply.)
answers: Give everyone time to speak.
Keep everyone involved by asking for feedback.
Have a clear structure.

question: When meeting with team members in-person, what are ways that culture is communicated? (Select all that apply.)
answers: The gestures we use
How we say goodbye
Posture and what we wear

question: What is often the first way that somebody might recognize that you are from a different culture?
answers: Noticing that you have a different accent

question: When challenged with a cultural difference, what should be done to address it and strengthen communication in the team?
answers: Identify the difference, find common ground, and communicate about how you want to work together.

question: Edward T. Hall is known for being one of the first to study which aspect of culture?
answers: How specific aspects can be compared across cultures

question: In high context cultures, what are nonverbal ways in which culture is communicated to others? (Select all that apply.)
answers: Hand gestures
Eye motions
Face expressions

question: What traits do low context cultures have in common? (Select all that apply.)
answers: Relationships tend to be short-term
People tend to be more focused on the individual than the group
Rules and standards are followed closely

question: What traits do high context cultures have in common? (Select all that apply.)
answers: People tend to be more focused on the group than the individual.
People tend to share a common history or religion.
Relationships tend to be long lasting and built to trust.

question: What is the main difference between high and low context cultures?
answers: High context cultrues use more nonverbal and indirect communication, while low context cultures use more spoken and direct communciation.

question: What did Renato have to say about Argentinians vs. Brazilians? (Select all that apply.)
answers: Argentinians enjoy sharing a popular local tea, referred to as maté, with each other, even in business settings; something Brazilians do not really do.
Argentinians are culturally closer to Europeans than most Brazilians.
Argentinians tend to dress more formally than Brazilians.

question: Which of the following nonverbal clues would indicate that a culture would likely prefer more formal communication? (Select all that apply.)
answers: Leaders expect to be driven, rather than to drive themselves, to and from official functions.
Introductions and greetings are structured, following clear protocol and showing deference to senior leaders.
Employees wear formal attire to the office in all types of weather conditions.

question: Imagine your colleague was invited to give a business presentation to a Silicon Valley start-up company and asks you for advice about how to behave. Knowing that Silicon Valley is generally an informal culture, which pieces of advice below would help them the most? (Select all that apply.)
answers: When you enter the room you might not know who is the senior-most person. That's ok, do not worry, hierarchy is not as important there.
If you are asked about your family or personal life, engage in the conversation and reciprocate with curiosity about their family or personal life.

question: When managing a MNCC team it is important to understand the level of formality your colleagues prefer. In order to learn whether they tend to be more formal or informal you could do which of the following: (Select all that apply.)
answers: Review the emails they are sending to you to see if they tend to be more structured and formal or more personal and relational. At your next update share your observations with them and ask for their thoughts.
Ask them to tell you more about customs and assumptions related to showing respect and honor in the workplace.
Gather the team together and discuss what you've learned regarding the formal/informal culture scale. Ask for them to share where they may be on that scale.

question: In addition to the areas we've discussed as indicators of a culture's location on the formal/informal scale, which of the items below might also provide useful clues? (Select all that apply.)
answers: Preferred communication tool and device (email, messaging app, phone)
Grammar and vocabulary
Rituals and practice related to gift-giving.
Body language

question: Which of these are essential elements of communication, according to the article in the section Oral vs. Written Communication? (Select all that apply.)
answers: Interference
Feedback

question: Which of these are oral applications of communication? (Select all that apply.)
answers: A telephone call
Dictating a text message using the voice function
Yelling down the hall to a coworker
Reading a question from the chat box out loud in a webinar

question: According to the author in the section Oral vs. Written Communication, why does it matter that written communications are asynchronous?
answers: There is no immediate feedback, so you need to try to anticipate the reader's needs, interpretation, and likely response.

question: What is one way that Borko's blog could be a direct communication to Gernot?
answers: He knows Gernot is a regular reader of his blog.

question: What might be an interference in the communication if Borko tagged Gernot's name? (Select all that apply.)
answers: Gernot no longer checks his Medium account.
Gernot turns off Medium notifications on his phone.
Borko misspelled Gernot's name when he tagged him.
Gernot cancelled his Medium profile.

question: According to the article from Social Media Week in the section Virtual Communication, which of these are ways technology impacts the way we think? (Select all that apply.)
answers: It removes us from moments.
It impedes our focus.
It changes how we read.

question: According to the article from Social Media Week in the section Virtual Communication, why does technology prompt FOMO (Fear of Missing Out)?
answers: It happens when you're doing something ordinary and you see pictures, videos, and posts from your friends who appear to be doing things that are more exciting.

question: According to Matthew Siu, which of these can be aspects of virtual communication? (Select all that apply.)
answers: Asynchronous
Permanence
Synchronous

question: Which of these are elements that will possibly or negatively affect the clarity in communication when utilizing virtual technologies? (Select all that apply.)
answers: Programs that check and correct word choice, spelling, and grammar.
Reliance on acronyms and shorthand.
Utilizing an internet connection.

question: How does vitural technology inhibit sharing your information in oral communication?
answers: We can not utilize body language as we would in an in-person conversation.

question: Security issues have always been present in business communication. But what new type of security issue has virutal technology created?
answers: Emotional security

question: According to Vignesh Ramachandran, why do we have excessive amounts of eye contact when we utilize video conferencing? (Select all that apply.)
answers: We are looking at everyone all the time.
A listener is treated nonverbally like a speaker.
The sizes of faces are unnatural.

question: Which types of fatigue does the Zoom Exhaustion & Fatigue Scale ask about?
answers: Social
Physical
Motivational
Emotional

question: In what ways are virtual teams and physical teams similar? (Select all that apply.)
answers: They both bring together individuals in order to accomplish more together than they can alone.
They both use rituals and artifacts to create and express their culture.

question: What options are there to transfer cultural activities from a physical space to a virtual space? (Select all that apply.)
answers: Replace
Re-create

question: How do virtual spaces alter our presentation of cultural artifacts? (Select all that apply.)
answers: We can set up our visual space behind us to showcase our culture.
People can learn personal cultural elements about us more quickly.
We only have to focus on dressing the top half of our body, or even just our face and neck.
We often have less control over cultural elements intruding into our space when we work at home.

question: According to the article in the lecture Culture in Virtual Workspaces, what shouldn't you do if there are technology or connection issues during a virtual meeting? (Select all that apply.)
answers: If the issues are on your end, you shouldn’t push to continue the meeting.
If the issues are on their end, you shouldn’t be afraid to suggest rescheduling.

question: According to the article in the lecture Culture in Virtual Workspaces, which of these are things that would be good to do before ending an effective virtual meeting? (Select all that apply.)
answers: Ask if there are any last questions and recap your main points.
Thank your clients for their trust in you.
Ask if there is anyone else the clients care about who may have concerns right now.

question: What does Mahee Thiagarajan recommend be “common denominators” for a virtual meeting to bridge cultural differences that may arise in a virtual meeting? (Select all that apply.)
answers: Minutes with action items
A structured agenda

question: Why do Mahee Thiagarajan and Manisha Gupta ask leaders to encourage questions in a virtual meeting to a greater extent than they might in person? (Select all that apply.)
answers: Your words have to represent your meaning and that alone isn’t always so clear.
When you're working together in the same room, debates are easier because people can recognize and control their emotions.
People are more likely to wait their turn to speak because it's not as clear when there is an appropriate moment to jump in without interrupting.

question: Why was Nancy Settle-Murphy told by her Japanese colleague that “In Japan, we sometimes say you have two ears, two eyes, and one mouth”?
answers: You have two eyes and two ears to observe and listen, and only one mouth to speak, so do less speaking and more listening.

question: According to Settle-Murphy, which of these are guidelines for great global virtual meetings? (Select all that apply.)
answers: Establish and enforce meeting norms
Set and control the pace

question: According to Settle-Murphy, what are guidelines that can best support non-native English speakers in a global team meeting?
answers: Identify and address miscommunication.

question: According to Manisha Gupta, which of these is the most effective way you can balance cultures that love a lot of context in emails and cultures that want to collect their own context?
answers: Put the ask at the top so they can read the rest in whatever way they like.

question: Which of these are parts of written communication that show up in Massimo and Daisuke’s communication that could change your interpretation of what they are saying? (Select all that apply.)
answers: Time stamps
Attachments
Emojis
Capitalization

question: According to Elsbach and Cable, what may be the result of working from home in a hybrid team, where others work from a shared office space? (Select all that apply.)
answers: Fewer promotions
Smaller raises
Lower performance evaluations

question: What were key findings they had about how face time affected employee evaluations? (Select all that apply.)
answers: Expected face time leads people to be seen as responsible or dependable.
Evaluations based on face time may be unconscious.
Extracurricular face time is of high value.

Managers are more likely to unconsciously attribute the traits “committed” and “dedicated” to people who put in extracurricular face time than to unconsciously attribute the traits “responsible” or “dependable” to people who put in expected face time.

question: How can you avoid the bias that comes from face time as either a manager or an employee?
answers: Use 360 degree feedback methodology to ensure that your bias from a manager perspective is outweighed by unbiased coworkers.

question: Which of these are some of the areas of difference between collectivism and individualism, according to Geoff Hofstede in his Cultural Dimensions Theory? (Select all that apply.)
answers: Assessment - Internal and External
Relational Mobility
Decision Making
Social Expectations

question: What of these showcase low relational mobility? (Select all that apply.)
answers: Long-lasting personal relationships.
Maintaining harmony and peace.
Putting time and energy into family and community.

question: How might you sing karaoke if you come from an individualistic culture? (Select all that apply.)
answers: Breaking up into different social groups to go sing.
In the main room at a bar with people both inside and outside your group.

question: Which of these statements below would mean you come from a culture with a monochronic relationship to time, or “m-time?” (Select all that apply.)

We’ve already wasted 15 minutes, can we please get to our original topic?!

question: Which of these are characteristics of flexible time cultures? (Select all that apply.)

question: Which of these are questions you might ask about the “what” for the goal section in an Empathy Map? (Select all that apply.)
answers: What decision do they want to make?
What does success look like for them?

question: Which of these are things Quân may be seeing that might change your opinion about why he is late?

question: Which of these might Quân be thinking or feeling based on what you capture from his observable activities? (Select all that apply.)
answers: He could be worried he is so busy with his job it is causing his family to eat unhealthy food too much.

question: Because you did an empathy map, if you were Quân’s supervisor, which of these would be the most likely outcome?

question: Which part of the Awareness Wheel includes things that are experienced through seeing, feeling, or hearing?

question: If somebody thinks this statement, what part(s) of the Awareness Wheel does it belong to?: "I am angry and disappointed. They should respect me." (Select all that apply.)

Thoughts

question: If somebody thinks this statement, what part(s) of the Awareness Wheel does it belong in?: “I believe it was a mistake. I will apologize.” (Select all that apply.)

Actions

question: According to the Awareness Wheel, if somebody thinks this to themself, which of them is an action?

question: Why is the Awareness Wheel useful in cross-cultural communication? (Select all that apply.)

question: Feedback is direct when it is expressed in a manner that is: (Select all that apply.)

Clear
Timely

question: How are "downgraders" typically used when giving feedback?

question: What is indirect feedback?

question: How can you give more effective feedback to someone from a direct feedback culture? (Select all that apply.)
answers: Tell them what they can improve on and include something positive about what they did.
Speak with them face-to-face.
Use "upgraders" to strengthen the message.

question: How can you give more effective feedback to someone from an indirect feedback culture? (Select all that apply.)
answers: Make information explicit by discussing communication norms and preferences.

Use "downgraders" to make the message less offensive.

question: In confrontational cultures, expressing disagreement is: (Select all that apply.)
answers: Considered productive and helpful
Thought to improve teamwork

question: In cultures that avoid confrontation, conflict is: (Select all that apply.)
answers: Understood as a confrontation of the person and not the idea
Considered rude and disrespectful

question: According to the video in the lecture Confrontation and Culture, which of these is swift trust? (Select all that apply.)
answers: People each assume the other is a professional and worthy of their trust.
Behavior in a conflict or negotiation justifies initial trust that people have in each other.

question: In cultures that avoid confrontation, people tend to express themselves: (Select all that apply.)
answers: Through stories, actions, or subtle cues
By asking a third party to share the message

question: In confrontational cultures, people tend to express themselves: (Select all that apply.)
answers: Directly, by stating the problem and how they would like it resolved

question: In cross-cultural communication, acting one way with one group and a different way with a different group is called:

question: When communicating across cultures, mirroring can be done by imitating another person or group’s: (Select all that apply.)
answers: Hand gestures
Body language

question: How does “double translation” reveal such a critical truth about why it’s not enough to learn another literal language, you need to learn another “cultural language”?
answers: When you translate something from one language to another, and then back to its original language, it can end up having a completely different meaning.

question: According to Dr. Rapaille, how do you “activate the local cultural logic of emotion”, or, in other words, capture not just another culture’s words, but their meaning?
answers: Tell the story of the word by giving an example of a situation to which the word applies.

question: According to Dr. Rapaille, countries each have a “code word” that has a very specific representative meeting for their culture as a whole. Which of these is not a code word she offers? (Select all that apply.)
answers: Russia - Cold

question: What makes code mixing different from code switching? (Select all that apply.)
answers: When you code mix you use words and grammatical elements from multiple sources at once, but when you code switch you use different words and grammatical elements in separate circumstances.
When you code mix you speak in a combination of styles, but when you code switch you change the style based on who you are speaking to.

question: Why does code mixing matter? (Select all that apply.)
answers: It allows us to authentically see ourselves reflected in our unique voices but also see a cohesive whole.
It helps others understand that you are open to learning and growing from their perspectives while equally inviting them to learn from your own.
It allows everyone, even in a small way, to see themselves in you.

question: What does the four-minute eye contact video have to do with MNCC teams?
answers: It doesn’t take long once people start speaking the same cultural language for them to feel a sense of trust and connection.

question: What are team norms?
answers: Team norms are a set of behaviors that appear over time that predict team members’ interactions.

question: What do team norms establish?
answers: Team norms establish clear, agreed-upon behavior, how the work will get done, and what team members can expect of each other.

question: Which of these is not a question the article asks you to consider when brainstorming team norms? Think of a time when you were part of a work team that accomplished something truly exceptional and consider:
answers: What did the organization do to contribute to this success?

question: Reviewing the ten steps for establishing team norms, which of these is an accurate statement?
answers: Team norms are documented.

question: What should you do once the team norms are in place? (Select all that apply.)
answers: As new members join your team, bring them up to speed and get their input on team norms.
Encourage meetings to address both the “what” and “how” of functioning as a team.
Make it a point to discuss what is working and what isn’t.
Keep the team norms to update add norms.

question: Our instructor Daniel Student developed a tool to “manage up” while working on a virtual team. In this tool, designed to be utilized to supplement weekly check-in meetings, he suggested including three categories. Which of the below made his list? (Select all that apply.)
answers: What I have done this week
What I will do this week

question: When working on a virtual multinational cross-cultural team it can be very difficult to build trust with your supervisor, especially if your supervisor is not used to this type of team. Ask your supervisor for feedback on your performance and your work style
Align your communication styles and tools

question: When working on a virtual MNCC team it is important to remember that each team member, including your boss, might have a different level of comfort with the virtual environment. What are some ways you might support your team members and their success? (Select all that apply.)
answers: Establish and/or regularly utilize a shared calendaring system that makes meeting availability transparent for everyone on the team
Train people who are new to the team on preferred tools and best practices
Ask around to find out preferred methods and tools for communication and see if a common agreement can be reached
Provide direct feedback about how one of your teammates can improve their performance during your next all-team call
Inform everyone you are hosting a family trivia night and that you hope your colleagues and their families can join you so that together you can build team morale

question: According to the article in the lecture Virutal Spaces and Teams, virtual team celebrations in the workplace can have several benefits. Which of these is a benefit listed in the article? (Select all that apply.)

Give your team a chance to break free from their regular schedule

question: Which of these are celebration ideas for virtual teams that the article suggests? (Select all that apply.)
answers: Virtual happy hours and cocktail parties
Icebreaker sessions
Board game night
Talent and creativity contests

question: Working on a virtual multinational cross-cultural team can have its challenges, but also has its unique advantages. Which of these is an advantage to virtual teams? (Select all that apply.)
answers: Meetings can be better structured to keep track of timing
The team can leverage online tools like Slack and Mural for collaboration and ideation

question: Organizing events for a virtual team can be difficult. There’s lots of technical issues to consider and people might not feel comfortable or willing to participate. Which of these are suggested ways to get started with planning a virtual celebration? (Select all that apply.)

Clearly define which achievement or events are worth celebrating

question: According to our panelists, which of these are ways you can use virtual technology to your benefit as a leader? (Select all that apply.)
answers: Using WhatsApp or WeChat to text across the world.
E-learning, learning-on-demand, training podcasts.
Collaboration tools where you can work on a document simultaneously.
Wiki page where everyone in the meeting can add their takeaways and then it is visible for everyone else.

question: According to Zenger Folkman, what is different about virtual leadership than in-person leadership? (Select all that apply.)
answers: Less personal, informal leadership moments
Increased necessity to be comfortable with technology
Less visibility to how your team members spend their time

question: Which of these is a suggestion from Zengar Folkman for a best practice in connecting with your team members?
answers: Remove all distractions and be present.

question: On virtual teams, how can team members know you are truly committed to them as a leader when they don’t see your day-to-day actions? (Select all that apply.)
answers: Ask for feedback.
Express interest in each team member’s development.
Bring a contagious energy and enthusiasm.

question: Leadership is primarily involved with which of the following activities (select all that apply).
answers: Empathizing and connecting with others

Breaking barriers and solving problems before they occur

question: In a previous module we discussed how to build trust with your supervisor. As Renato noted, building trust with others is a key aspect of leadership. Why is building personal trust so important for leaders? (Select all that apply.)
answers: People will follow someone they believe has their back and their best interests in mind

answers: Treating adaptive challenges like technical problems

question: When working with multinational and cross-cultural teams, cultural differences can often lead to challenges. Why is adaptive leadership so important for MNCC teams? (Select all that apply.)
answers: Adaptive leadership can help leaders manage challenges, particularly cultural differences, in a way that motivates the team to work better together.

question: According to Derek Sivers in his TED talk, why is the first follower in a movement so important?

question: Based on the Indeed article, why is developing a leadership style important to employers?

question: The servant leadership style:
answers: Is good for improving employee productivity and loyalty
Focused on group discussions and consensus

question: Which leadership style is characterized by inspiring employees and helping create trust for new ideas?

question: How can you identify your own leadership style? (Select all that apply.)
answers: Ask for feedback.
Experiment
Be authentic.

question: When discussing leadership our interviewees mentioned and highlighted each of the three tests of leadership versus management we read about in this module. answers: Salonan He or she generates value over and above that which the team creates, and is as much a value-creator as his or her followers are. Leading by example and leading by enabling people are the hallmarks of action-based leadership.

question: When discussing leadership our interviewees mentioned and highlighted each of the three tests of leadership versus management we read about in this module. answers: Mahee When they stop discussing the tasks at hand — and talk about vision, purpose, and aspirations instead, that's when you will know you have become a leader.

question: When discussing leadership our interviewees mentioned and highlighted each of the three tests of leadership versus management we read about in this module. answers: Renato Just as managers have subordinates and leaders have followers, managers create circles of power while leaders create circles of influence.

question: According to our panel, which of these are ways your cultural background can influence how you see great leadership? (Select all that apply.)

Your native culture's values.
Your parents or family.
Living abroad.

question: According to Hewlett and Rashid in their research on gender in leadership, what is the main skill that all global leaders, regardless of gender, need?
answers: The ability to pivot.

question: According to Hewlett and Rashid’s research, how are women supposed to demonstrate authority and deliver a compelling message in most cultures?
answers: Assertive and facilitating others.

question: According to P. Christopher Earley and Elaine Mosakowski, which of these are sources of intelligence? (Select all that apply.)
answers: Body Intelligence
Head Intelligence

question: According to Early and Mosakowski, what is heart intelligence?
answers: Relying on instinct of what someone from another culture is really feeling instead of what you are hearing or seeing.

question: What does Geoff Hofstede’s Power Distance Index measure?

question: Which of these are behaviors you would expect from people from egalitarian cultures? (Select all that apply.)
answers: Disagreement with a boss, even in a public situation.
Direct interactions with senior management from lower-level employees.

question: According to Natalie Halcrow’s blog on how to tell the difference between hierarchical and egalitarian cultures, which of these are signposts of hierarchical cultures?
answers: Rituals for greeting and communicating are very structured, especially with older generations.
Titles and honorifics are often used.

question: If you are a manager who has an employee from a Scandinavian Country and an employee from an East Asian country, what might you expect from the relationships? (Select all that apply.)
answers: One employee might invite you for a drink after work and one employee might sit far away during social interactions.

question: In top-down cultures decisions are generally made: (Select all that apply.)

By those at the top of the power hierarchy

question: Which of the following are true of decisions made in consensual cultures? (Select all that apply.)

Plans tend to be inflexible after implementation
Opinions of all parties involved are sought out and listened to carefully

question: Imagine your team consisted of you and five other people. Two of the other team members work in your home country, one works in Japan, another in Germany, and the last in the United States. Your team will prefer a top-down approach

Good communication skills

question: Which of the following actions can a leader do to encourage a victim and villain to see themselves as a creator and challenger? (Select all that apply.)

Provide advice and ask questions that allow the victim and villain to feel empowered.

Desire to learn

question: How can cultural factors explain the different worldviews of different generations?
